youtube.title: Why I Do Science: Danielle Reed - QUEST Philadelphia
youtube.caption: Dr. Danielle Reed of the Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, PA, became interested in science at an early age, based on her experiences with sensory experiences. She recognized that she had a different ability to taste bitterness compared to other people she knew. Now, she studies the genetic differences between people in their sensitivities to taste stimuli. In the video, there is a brief image of a person sticking out their tongue covered with a colored dye. This is how Dr. Reed is able to visualize papillae on the surface of the tongue and count how many there are for a research subject. People fall into two large groups, known as “tasters” and “non-tasters” based on the density of papillae on their tongue, which is also a sign of the number of taste buds. Non-tasters can taste food, but they are not as sensitive to some stimuli, like Dr. Reed is to bitterness.
